dialogues.text: Indy walks into this perfect little American town--- --the three Russians in the American jeep cruise slowly a corner, still searching for Indy. Indy jumps over a fence into the backyard of a prim house  19 20 21

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Hello?! Hello?! Anybody home?! Indy grabs the phone, the phone line is broken. He hears faint MUSIC form the other room.

dialogues.speaker: INT LIVING ROOM DUSK
dialogues.text: Indy races into the living room, where the music is loude the theme from the Howdy Doody Show. A family (MOM, DAD, KIDS) is seated with their backs to him, watching Howdy o black and white TV set.

dialogues.text: Hey, hey, Russians ..... (or on C) I knocked. You guys got a telephone. Nobody moves. Nobody answers. They just stare at the scre INDY (cont’d) Wait a minute. Hey, Dad isn’t a dad at all and Mom isn’t a mom and in fa aren’t even real people! They’re MANNEQUINS.

dialogues.text: Why, Howdy, haven’t you guessed yet? It’s an imaginary place! Indy is stunned, trying to process what’s happening. He goes to the front door and steps out--  22

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: T-minus ten seconds and counting. Indy yanks everything out of the fridge, shelves and all. VOICE (0.S.) (cont'd) T-minus five seconds and counting. Indy jumps into the fridge and SLAMS the door -- VOICE (0.S.) (cont’d) Four. -- but the door bounces open, cans are blocking it -- VOICE (0.S.) (cont'd) Three. -- he cleans the rest of the things out -- VOICE (0.S.) (cont’d) Two. -- and SLAMS the door. As it closes a little metal plate corner of the door pops into focus, it reads -- VOICE (0.S.) (cont’d) One. -- “LEAD-LINED FOR SUPERIOR INSULATION!” The screen turns white.  26 27

dialogues.speaker: IN THE INCREDIBLE GLARE,
dialogues.text: Mannequins fly apart in the blast-furnace, bodies ignite matchheads, Kids are swept off their bikes, Mailman and Pedestrian turn to cinders in a split-second, the Buick a waving Driver tumble down the street like a flaming toy. Walls collapse, houses implode, roofs fly away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT DESERT DUSK
dialogues.text: A mile away, the Russian Soldiers are driving like madmen getting out of town at eighty miles an hour, but it isn’t enough, as a BLASTWAVE OF HEAT AND DEBRIS comes rocketing the blast, turning sand to glass. And in the instant before the blastwave consumes them, th thing the Russians see is -- -- a REFRIGERATOR zipping past them, riding the blastwave And then the Russians are vaporized, their jeep melting i desert sand. We are engulfed by dust.

dialogues.speaker: EXT DESERT DUSK
dialogues.text: A couple miles from Doom Town, the dust billows away to r scorched, half-melted refrigerator lying in a pile of deb We hear THUMPING from within, the latch gives, and the do swings up with a heave. Indy emerges, unsteady on his fee staggers toward us, A prairie dog is watching him

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What are you looking at? Indy gets up and grabs his whip from the refrigerator, he up the hill. As he settles gazing up with horror and awe at -- A HUGE MUSHROOM CLOUD, rising up over the desert floor. I stands there, silhouetted against the billowing, seething and is it our imagination or, with its creepy, hollowed-o sockets, does that deadly cloud bear a strong resemblance -- to a human skull?

dialogues.speaker: INT DECONTAMINATION ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Indy, exhausted, is in a decontamination room He’s surrou by FOUR SOLDIERS in medical gowns and goggles who are scr him roughly with long-handled brushes. Two shadowy men in dark suits and skinny ties, SMITH and stand a short distance away, regarding him suspiciously. MAN with a Geiger counter waves a metal wand across Indy’ There are few, if any, CLICKS. A SOLDIER IN UNIFORM enters and hands smith a paper. He e the room. Indy is seated on a table, Taylor is standing o other side.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Your story appears to check out. But I’m still mystified, Dr. Jones, as to why you were in the Russian car in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I told you, I was knocked unconscious and kidnapped from a dig in Mexico. I woke up I was in the trunk of that car

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Along with your good friend George McHale?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I had no reason to believe Mac was a spy. He was MI6 when I was 0.S.S., we did twenty or thirty missions together in Europe and the Pacific, we-

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Don’t wave your war record in our face, Colonel Jones, we all served.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: No kidding? What side were you on? Smith starts to walk in back of Indy, as Taylor crosses i

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I don’t think you understand the gravity of your situation. You aided and abetted KGB operatives who broke into a (he sits) secret military installation, in the heart of the United States of America. My country.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What was in that steel box they took?

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: You tell us. You’ve seen it before.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You mean that Air force fiasco in ‘47? I was tossed into a bus with blacked out windows and twenty people I wasn’t allowed to speak(talk) to-- hauled out in the middle of the night to the middle of nowhere on some urgent recovery project and shown - what? Pieces of wreckage and an intensely magnetic shroud covering--(still unsure what it was)-- mutilated remains? None of us were every given the full picture and we were threatened with treason if we ever talked about it. So you tell me-- what was in the box?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: This process works best when we ask the question, Dr. Jones.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Mummified remains?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Our records don’t indicate anything of that nature was housed there.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: You must be confused, Dr. Jones.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: the only thing that facility stores is replacement parts for B series aircraft. * He HHH HH HH HH HF *

dialogues.text: The door BANGS open and a two-star Army General barrels i room -- GENERAL ROSS. Around Indy’s age, big man, big voi

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ROSS
dialogues.text: Indy, thank God! Don’t you know it’s dangerous to climb into a refrigerator? Those things are death traps! Ross is smiling, he’s kidding. Indy smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Good to see you too, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ROSS
dialogues.text: (to Smith and Taylor) Relax, boys, I can vouch for Dr. Jones.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (to Ross) What the hell’s going on? KGB on American soil? Who was that woman?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Describe her.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Tall, thin, mid-thirties. She carried a sword of some kind -- a rapier, I think. Knew how to use it, too. Smith and Taylor exchange a look -- they recognize that description. Taylor steps out of the room quickly. Through a glass panel, we see Taylor, outside the room, p phone and make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross produces a file from his briefcase and flips it open showing Indy a surveillance photograph of Spalko. Indy pi the file and looks at it. INDY (cont’d) Yeah, that’s her.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (to Indy) You’re sure she’s here?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Here and gone. Who is she? Smith doesn’t answer Indy. But General Ross does.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ROSS
dialogues.text: Irina Spalko, Stalin’s fair-haired girl. His favorite scientist, if you can call psychic research science. Smith steps in, trying to end this conversation. Indy loo through the file.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: General Ross.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ROSS
dialogues.text: She’s leading teams from the Kremlin all over the world, scooping up artifacts she thinks might have paranormal military applications. She’s-

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: General Ross. Smith takes the file from Indy and closes it. Ross turns, Smith gives him an icy glare.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ROSS
dialogues.text: Back off, Paul. Not everyone in the Army is a Commie. And certainly not Indy. Ross sits at the head of the table. Indy also sits and pu feet up.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What exactly am I being accused with, besides surviving a nuclear blast? Outside, Taylor hangs up the phone and re-enters the room

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Nothing yet. But frankly, your association with George McHale calls into question all your activities, including those during the war.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ROSS
dialogues.text: are you nuts? Do you have any idea how many medals this son of a bitch has won?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: A great many, I’m sure. But does he deserve them?

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Dr. Jones, let’s just say for now that you are of interest to the Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Of great interest.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Look, you got any doubts about me, talk to congressman Freleng. Or Abe Portman in Army Intel. Hell, ask anybody, I’ve got a lot of friends in Washington!

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I think, Professor, you’1l find you might be wrong about that.

dialogues.speaker: EXT UNIVERSITY CAMPUS DAY
dialogues.text: A beautiful college campus. A big banner tells us Homecom this Saturday. But OMINOUS FOOTSTEPS echo over the quad. is

dialogues.speaker: INT CAMPUS BUILDING DAY
dialogues.text: a pair of dress shoes CLICK down a hallway in one of the buildings. DEAN CHARLES STANFORTH, sixtyish, stops at a d looks

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW,
dialogues.text: we see Indy, dressed in his tweedy professor’s garb, teac class.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: --a period of time distinguished with the use of Groove Ware and the beginnings of modern drainage practices which we also see in Skara Brae, on the west coast of Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CLASSROOM,
dialogues.text: Stanforth slips quietly inside and leans against the wall

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Skara Brae dates back to 3100 B.C. And was continuously occupied for a period of about six hundred years until its apparent abandonment in 2500 B.C. There’s no clear(solid) evidence as to why its- He stops and looks at Stanforth. Stanforth looks grim. In stumbles, knows something's up. INDY (cont’d) Its inhabitants decided to abandon to, uh, leave a perfectly healthy settlement(environment) (to Stanforth) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: May I have a moment, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Yes of course. Indy turns back in and addresses his class. INDY (cont’d) Uh, open up Michaelson, review chapter four. When I come back we’1l discuss the difference between migration(emigration) and exodus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 27. He steps into the hall, closing the door behind him. The STUDENTS lean forward to hear what’s going on outside INDY (0.S.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: The Students look up sharply. Indy and the Dean are visib through the glass; Indy looks like he’s going to clobber

dialogues.speaker: OUT IN THE HALLWAY,
dialogues.text: Stanforth’s trying to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: You have no idea the pressure coming from the Board of Regents. The FBI showed up this morning, they ransacked your office, searched all your files --

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: And you didn’t stop them? You’re the dean of this college, they have no right! *

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: They had every right! They weren’t vandals, they were federal agents with search warrants. The University’s not going to let itself be embroiled in that kind of controversy, not in this * charged climate. * Indy leads Stanforth down the hallway. *

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: So you’re firing me?

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: A leave of absence, is all. An * indefinite leave of absence --

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You are firing me!

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: -- during which they have agreed to continue to pay your full salary for a period of-

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I don’t want their money. I’11 tell you * what they can do with their money. *  27A.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: Please don’t be foolish, you don’t know what I had to go through to get that for you.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What you went through?(what you had to go through?) What exactly did you have to go through, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: Henry. I resigned. Indy just looks at him, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 34 28. INT INDY’S HOUSE DAY Indy is folding a shirt, he puts it in a suitcase that’s bed in Indy’s bedroom. Stanforth is standing in the archway. They’re halfway thr bottle of red wine, middle of the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: Where will you go?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Train to New York, overnight to London, for starters. Might end up teaching in Leipzig, Heinrich owes me a favor Indy moves to the closet, opens up one of the drawers and out some clothes. He moves back to the bed. INDY (cont’d) I’1l wire you when I get settled and you can send the rest of my things He goes back to the closet and gets a couple of belts, he back to the packing.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: I suppose there’s nothing to keep you here. I barely recognize this country anymore, the government’s got us seeing communists in our soup. When the hysteria reaches academia, I guess it’s time to call it a career. Indy picks up his glass and moves to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: How’d Deirdre take the news? Stanforth follows.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: How does any wife take such things? The look on her face was a combination of pride and panic. Stanforth finishes his drink. Indy moves to his desk and the drawers.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I never should have doubted you, my friend.  29.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: We seem to be at the age where life stops giving us things and starts taking them away. Pause. Wow, bummer. Then they both snap out of it at the time, Indy bolting up to resume packing while Stanforth r for the wine. STANFORTH (cont'd) Maybe just another half a glass... Indy goes to his desk and rifles through some papers, tak few, including his passport, throws out some others. STANFORTH (cont'd) I wish you’d met someone like Deirdre, to help you through times like this. Or if you’d realized it when you did meet her...

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Let’s not tug on that thread right now, okay pal? Stanforth holds his hands up in surrender, okay, I’1l dro He notices his watch.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: Good Lord, I’ve got to get home. Don and Maggie are driving spousum et familia up from the city for dinner. Emergency family council meeting.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (with a touch of envy) They’re good kids.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: Healthy and employed, I’1l settle for that. I’m off. (stands, sways from the wine) And I believe I should walk.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Thank you for what you did, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: I cut quite the dramatic figure. The Regents were stunned into shamed silence. At least that’s the way I'll tell it to the grandkids.  29A.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: Healthy and employed, I’1l settle for that. I’m off. (stands, sways from the wine) And I believe I should walk.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Good idea. Indy stands and moves to Stanforth. He fixes his jacket INDY (cont’d) Thank you my friend, for what you did.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: I cut quite the dramatic figure.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I bet you did. They move towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: STANFORTH
dialogues.text: the Regents were stunned into shamed silence. At least that’s the way I'll tell it to the grandchildren. Indy opens the front door. Stanforth turns to Indy with o thought . STANFORTH (cont'd) you know, when you’re young you spend all your time thinking “Who will I be?” And for years you’re busy shouting at the world “this is who I am!” But lately I’ve been wondering -- after I’m gone, who will they say I was? Stanforth leaves. Indy looks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Bye Charlie. He closes the door.  35 36 30.

dialogues.speaker: EXT TRAIN STATION DAY
dialogues.text: -- and we’re at the train station, the sound is the train WHISTLE as it gets ready to pull out. Indy gets out of a the parking lot. A sedan arrives with DIMITRI and his two ASSOCIATES--all in suits. When Dimitri looks to his associate in the back the man give him the “go ahead.” They pull away. As Indy hurries up the steps to the platform carrying his suitcase, a “Harley Davidson” MOTORCYCLE glides to a halt Indy walks down the platform between two trains. Pausing step of his train car, he glances back to his city. And j he steps into the car, two of the men in suits slip aboar other end of the train. They are following him. After Indy finds his seat, a MOTORCYCLE RIDER in a black jacket, jeans, boots, cap, and leather gloves cruises up platform. He seems to be looking for someone. MUTT WILLIAMS is twenty, American, and impatient. As the WHISTLE blows one last time, he spots Indy. Mutt whips the bike into a quick turn.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PLATFORM
dialogues.text: The train starts to pull out of the station. Mutt pulls even with Indy’s train car, and SHOUTS to him.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Hey! Mister! Hey, buddy! (louder ) Hey Professor! Indy turns. MUTT (cont’d) Are you Dr. Jones? Indy nods, then look sup ahead, at the end of the platfor

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You’re running out of platform, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. Mutt SHOUTS:

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You’re a friend of Dr. Oxley, right? Indy turns back. He knows the name.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Harold Oxley, the archaeologist?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: They’re going to kill him. Indy grabs his bag and gets off the train. 37 Omitted

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 38 32. INT BERNIE’S DINER DAY Saturday afternoon. Letter sweaters, saddle shoes, a juke playing “wake up Little Suzie” Mostly COLLEGE TYPES in th place, but a dozen GREASERS in the back drinking beer, lo for trouble. A LETTERMEN walks up to the jukebox about to select a son the GREASERS puts his hand on his head and spins around, Lettermen walks back to his table Indy and Mutt are in the diner, a waitress pours coffee a table Mutt turns his hat over and picks up a photograph hands i Indy. CLOSE ON a photograph of Mutt, a few years younger, standing next to a BOOKISH MAN in his mid-fifties, more b down than the second floor of Brooks Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: INDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I haven’t talked to Harold Oxley in twenty years. We lost touch. We had a falling out. He cut me off, angry about something or other. I never found out about what it was. Too bad, he’s a brilliant guy. He could put you to sleep by talking though.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: when I was a kid, that’s how I did get to sleep. The Ox was better than a glass of warm milk.(offers his hand) Name’s Mutt Williams.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: “Mutt?” What kind of name is that?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: It’s the one I picked, you got a problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Take it easy. What was Oxley your uncle or something? (what was your relationship to Oxley?)

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Kind of. My dad died in the war and the Ox helped my mom raise me. He pulls a comb from his back pocket and dips it in a gla coke on the table next to him. He runs it through his car kept hair.  32A.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You said they were going to kill him. Mutt puts his comb away and leans in closer to Indy.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: About six months ago my mom got a letter from the Ox. He was down in Peru. He said he found some kind of skull, crystal skull, like the one that guy Mitchell- Hodgkins, Mitchell-Hodgkins found.  33. He turns and grabs a bottle of beer off the tray of a WAI serving the table next to them. (She doesn’t see.)

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: The Ox and I were obsessed with the Mitchell-Hedges skull when we were in college. How do you know about it? Indy takes the beer from Mutt and puts it back on the Wai tray. (She doesn’t see that either.)

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You kidding? Ox could talk about that thing till the cows came home. That’s all he talked about. What was it, like an idol?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It’s a deity carving. Meso-American. There’s a few crystal skulls in the world. I saw one in the British Museum. They’re impressive craftsmanship, but that’s about it.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Oxley said the skull had psychic powers.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Like, “Stare into its eyes and it’ll drive you crazy?”

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Laugh all you want, but Ox said he found it this time. This was real, and he was on his way to a place called Akator with it. Indy sits forward -- now he’s interested.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Akator?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Akator.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: He said that? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Akator, that’s what he said. (or)Yeah. What is it?  33A.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It’s a mythical, a lost city in the Amazon. The Conquistadors called it El Dorado. Supposedly the Ugha tribe were chosen by the gods 7,000 years ago to build a great(giant) city out of solid gold. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INDY (cont’d) With aqueducts, paved roads, technology that wouldn’t be sees again for another five thousand years. Francesco de Orellana disappeared into the Amazon looking for it in 1546. I almost died(myself) of typhus(myself) looking for it. I don’t think it exists.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Why would Ox want to take the skull there?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: The legend says that a crystal skull was stolen from Akator in the fifteenth or sixteenth century. That whoever returns this skull to the city’s temple will be given control over its power. (powers)

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Power? (powers) (so there is some kind of power)What kind of power?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, kid. It’s just a story.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: From his letter, my mom thought the Ox was off his rocker. (taps his head) Smog in the noggin’. Goes down to find him, only he had already been kidnapped, and now they’ve got her too. Ox hid(buried) the skull somewhere, and if my mom doesn’t come up with it, they’re gonna kill ‘em both. She said you’d help me.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Me? What’s your mom’s name, again?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Mary, Mary williams. You remember her?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: There were a lot of Mary’s, kid. Mutt slams the table and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Shut up, man, your talking about my mother. That’s my mother. Don’t, alright, that’s my mother!  34A.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Look, you don’t have to get sore all the time to prove how tough you are, okay? Sit down, relax, please sit down. You want my help or not?  35.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: My mom said if anybody could find the skull it’s you. Like you’re some type of grave robber or something.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I’m a teacher.(I’m a professor) ( I’ma tenure professor)

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You’re a teacher. (perfect- just our luck, just my luck you’re a teacher. You’re a teacher that’s a big help. That should be a big help. You’re a teacher great I love teachers) She called me two weeks ago from South America, told me she escaped but they were after her. She said she’d just mailed me a letter from the Ox, and I was suppose to give it to you. Then the line went dead. Mutt pulls an envelope from his jacket and gives it to In opens it and pulls out a single page. MUTT (cont’d) I opened it. It’s pointless the thing’s gibberish, though, it’s not even English lettering.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. He nods toward the soda counter-- the two bulky Guys from train station have followed them here. INDY (cont’d) Those two bricks over at the counter Are not here for the milkshakes. He follows their gaze down to the letter he holds in his They seem awfully interested in it, suddenly alert. Indy folds the letter and slips it in his jacket pocket a bulky Guys approach the table.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: who are they?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe FBI. The Bulky Guys arrive at the table. They speak with Russi accents.  35A.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN 1
dialogues.text: Come quietly, Dr. Jones.  36.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Make that KGB.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN 1
dialogues.text: And bring letter with you.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (to the Russian) Letter? What letter?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN 1
dialogues.text: Letter Mr. Williams just give you.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Do I look like a mailman?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN 2
dialogues.text: We don’t ask again. Come now or-

dialogues.speaker: CLICK
dialogues.text: Mutt has popped open a switchblade, which he holds behind folded arms, it’s long nasty blade shining in the light.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Or what?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Nice try, kid, but I think you brought a knife --

dialogues.speaker: CLICK CLICK
dialogues.text: Both Russians take out their handguns pointing out from t jackets. INDY (cont’d) -- to a gunfight.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN 1
dialogues.text: (gesturing) Outside. Now. Indy puts his hat on and grabs his briefcase. Mutt picks hat, and puts his knife away. They both start to move out The Russians lead them across the crowded diner, walking behind them, their hands inside their coats menacingly. Indy looks around, thinking wildly. The pass A LETTERMEN standing, talking to a GIRL IN A POO eCUTDT/CACLIAY  36A. Indy looks at them, and at Mutt.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (to Mutt) Punch that guy.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Who?  37.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (gesturing to the Letterman) Joe College. Hit him. Hard. Mutt gets it. He grins --

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Hold this.(motioning with his hat) -- the guy turns, and Mutt SMASHES him in the face. There SHOUTS and SCREAMS from around them as the Letterman goes

dialogues.speaker: GIRL IN THE POODLE SKIRT, (SASHA)
dialogues.text: That’s my boyfriend. She punches Mutt, and then the Letterman punches Mutt. Mutt lands next to the GREASERS, they take off their glas get ready. Indy grabs the girl and pushes her aside, he hurls his su pushes a table, it falls blocking the Russians. The Russians see what’s happening and try to move through crowd, towards Indy, -- Indy sees them approaching, he pu hat on one of the students and ducks.

dialogues.speaker: GET THAT GREASER
dialogues.text: THEY ALL LEAP into the fray, swinging chairs and fists. M They leap into the fray, swinging chairs and fists. Mayhe Somebody’s tossed into the jukebox; “Wake up Little Suzie over to “Shake, Rattle and Roll.” Mutt and Indy take off, headed for the front door The Russians fight to get to Indy and Mutt but it’s chaos they can’t get to them before they’re out the door.  39 38.

dialogues.speaker: INT ALLEY DAY
dialogues.text: Indy and Mutt race down the sidewalk, where Mutt’s motorc parked. Mutt, putting on his gloves, leaps on board, Indy thinks, fast:

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Your mom didn’t escape, they let her go. So she could mail the letter, and you could bring it to me and I could translate it.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: (kicks it to life with a ROAR) Get on Grumps, time to cut out! Indy has no choice but to hop on the bike. Mutt hits the the bike kicks a wheelie as it ROARS out of the alley. The Russians finally make it out of the diner. A girl gra of Russian #1’s neck. He throws her off, they look around hem at the bikes. They run down the sidewalk. The Russian sedan’s SCREECH around a corner and pull up t They get in, the cars roar out after them.  40 4l 42 38A.

dialogues.speaker: ON BOARD THE BIKE,
dialogues.text: Indy clings to Mutt as the kid races through the used-to- peaceful American streets. They’re putting distance betwe themselves and the Russian sedan, but now a -- -- SECOND SEDAN ROARS out of a side street and pulls up a them on the left. The sedan edges over toward Mutt, both at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: DIMITRI
dialogues.text: BLIZHEI! (closer) Mutt’s got no room to maneuver, they’re squeezing him up alongside a speeding bus, they’re getting crushed. RUSSIA reach out the open back window of the sedan. Indy turns and punches Dimitri, his hat flies off. The Ru grabs hold of Indy --

dialogues.speaker: DIMITRI
dialogues.text: SVOLOCH! (bastard) TEPER TRIMOI! (now you’re mine) -- and drag him right off the motorcycle!

dialogues.speaker: INT RUSSIAN CAR DAY
dialogues.text: Indy gets hauled into the back seat of the Russian sedan, KICKS the driver, knocking off his hat, then turns and PU DIMITRI, until he knocks him out. Indy crawls, toward the window on the other side of the seat.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE BACK WINDOW,
dialogues.text: we can see Mutt drop behind the car, then gun the bike an up, approaching the left side of the sedan. Indy gets a hold of the window frame and boosts himself o the window- -

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET DAY
dialogues.text: -- and is hanging half out of the car when Mutt ROARS up alongside him. Indy grabs onto the motorcycle but doesn’t quite nail the landing. Hanging onto the bar on the back of the seat, he dragged behind the motorcycle for a good fifty yards befo sees what’s going on --  44 45 39. -- TAPS the brakes -- -- and Indy sails up into the air, over the slowing motor SLAMS into Mutt’s back, and lands hard on the seat behind The bus and sedan continue down the street as the bike pe across oncoming traffic and through an iron gate. The bla follows crashing through the closing iron gate, breaking gate on one side as it goes through. The bike and sedan#2 continue through the courtyard and t leads the sedan through an archway tunnel and into anothe area. The sedan continues chasing the bike up to the point wher bike goes through a narrow passageway with a gothic arch. passageway is too narrow and the sedan has to stop. The s then backs away from the passageway. The bike continues on through a series of archway passage people jump out of the way. At the end of the last archway the bike enters the flow o traffic again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sedan chases the bike again as it re-enters traffic u bike turns off the road... Onto a smaller walkway, and then turns off the walkway an up the stairs into the library. The sedan stops and then backs out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BUSY STREET DAY
dialogues.text: -- onto a busy street, where Mutt guns it. The #1 sedan h the corner and sees them drive by. Dimitri yells at the d follow them. The sedan is immediately on them again givin as Mutt heads for: He drives through another archway and into an open field middle of the buildings.

dialogues.speaker: THE CENTER OF TOWN,
dialogues.text: where there’s a demonstration going on, a SPEAKER, banner placards. The motorcycle zips neatly through them, but th isn’t so nimble. A STUDENT leaps out of the way of the sedan and his placa across the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE SEDAN,
dialogues.text: we can read the placards--as they hit the windshield. Mutt gets the idea to run over the large “BETTER DEAD THA SIGN. He runs the motorcycle through the pole, the sign f the windshield. The car drives blindly, it tears apart.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 48 40. The car SMASHES into the base of a statue of Marcus Brody The crash causes the head of the statue to break off, it down and crashes through the windshield. It lands on the lap. Mutt and Indy watch. Mutt is happy with himself. The seco appears out of the nearby archway. Mutt takes off, the se chases after them. As Mutt ROARS AWAY, Dimitri and the driver get out of the The driver hands the head to Dimitri, he drops the head.  43 40A.

dialogues.speaker: INT LIBRARY DAY
dialogues.text: -- the school library. The bike ROARS into the main readi room, sending books and magazines flying into the air. ST dive out of the way, Indy SHOUTS .

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: This is the library, you’re going too fast!

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Hey, hey! Split, split. Move, move, get out of the way! Students dive out of the way, one student carrying an arm books is standing still, he screams. Mutt sees him and also screams, he turns, just missing th student. His wheels spin out from under him and the bike down, right in the middle of the reading room. Mutt and Indy slide across the room , crashing under the They come to a stop, right in front of a seated student.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Dr. Jones.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I’ve got a quick question about Hargrove’s normative culture models -- Mutt gets up, Indy hops on the back of the bike.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Forget Hargrove. Read Vere Gordon Childe on diffusionism, he spent most of his life in the field. Mutt kicks the bike’s starter and it ROARS back to life. INDY (cont’d) If you wanna be a good archaeologist you gotta -- Mutt guns it and the bike takes off, Indy SHOUTING back - INDY (cont’d)

dialogues.speaker: -- GET OUT OF THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: The hike ROARS awav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 41. EXT INDY’S HOUSE DUSK Indy goes to the bookshelves. He pulls down a thick book, to a section in the middle. He moves to the couch. Mutt i looking around.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: is this your pad? It’s the first place they’11 look for us, we should get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Just give me a minute. Indy sits and pulls Oxley’s letter from his pocket and st it. He pulls a pair of glasses from his pocket and slips He compares the symbols there with the symbols in Oxley’s Mutt looks at himself in the mirror, he starts to comb hi INDY (cont’d) Just what I thought so. Koihoma.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: An extinct Latin American language. (he grabs a small journal and a pencil) Pre- Columbian syllabary system. See these diagonal stresses on the ideogams? Definitely Koihoma.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You speak it? Mutt takes out a stick of gum and begins to chew.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Nobody speaks it, it hasn’t been heard out loud in three thousand years. Might be able to read a little -- He flips to another page, further in the book, also cover ancient symbols. He MUTTERS to himself, comparing the two and scribbling on the journal. INDY (cont’d) -- if I walk it through Mayan first.  42.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You know, for an old man, you ain’t bad in a fight.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: So what are you, like eighty? Still working, Indy laughs through the desire to punch Mu the face. Doesn’t look at him.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Hard livin’, kid. I am not recommending it. He holds up the page he’s written, reading from it. INDY (cont’d) “Follow the lines in the earth that only the gods can read which lead to Orellana’s cradle, guarded by the living dead.” (an idea) Only the gods can read. He’s talking about the Nazca Lines.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What are those? Indy stands and goes back to the book shelf.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Geoglyphs. Here we go. He finds the book and walks back to Mutt, he flips throug searching for a certain page. INDY (cont’d) Giant ancient drawings, scratched into the desert floor in Peru. From the ground they don’t look like anything, but from the air (sky)-- ah! He spins the book around to face Mutt, who bends over to it. Two whole pages are devoted to serial photographs of beautiful carvings in the Peruvian desert. One looks like monkey, another like a spider, a hummingbird -- and a lar headed humanoid figure.  50 43. INDY (cont’d) Only the gods can read them, because the gods -- (gesturing) -- live up there.(this is before airplanes) Oxley’s telling us the skull is in Nazca, Peru. And it’s a good bet the Russians are the ones who have him. The Kremlin probably think the skull has some potential as a weapon, that’s why they’re after it.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: If it gets my mom back, they can have it. Let’s go, and try not to slow me down. Mutt starts to head for the door, but Indy is thinking

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Akator. That would be the find of a lifetime. Indy moves to the bedroom INDY (cont’d) Create a reputation no politician could touch. INT INDY’S BEDROOM DUSK BAM! Indy SMACKS open the closet door in his bedroom. His is still there, in the foreground, and the whip is curled top shelf, the handle sticking out.  43A. RETAKE 8-31-07- INT. INDY’S HOUSE- DUSK

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: So what are you , like, eighty? Still working, Indy looks up holding the letter

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It’s a riddle. Leave it to Oxley to write a riddle in a dead language. “Follow the lines in the earth that only the gods can read which led to Orellana’s cradle, guarded by the living dead.”(an Idea- he gets up) he’s talking about the Nazca Lines. Indy walks to back to the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What are those? (what are they?) Indy grabs a large book.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Here we go. Geoglyphs. He walks back to Mutt, flips through it, finds the page. pages are devoted to aerial photographs of beautiful carv the Peruvian desert. One looks like a monkey, another lik spider, a hummingbird -- and a large headed humanoid figu INDY (cont’d) Giant ancient drawings, carved into the desert floor in Nazca Peru. From the ground they don’t look like much(anything) but from the sky-- (he takes his glasses off) Only the gods can read, because only gods- (gesturing) live up there. Oxley’s telling us the skull is in Nazca, Peru. And it’s a good bet the Russians have him. The Kremlin probably thinks the skull has some potential as a weapon, that’s why they’re after it.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Look teach, if it gets my mom back, they can have whatever they want. Let’s go(let’s split) Mutt starts to head for the door, but Indy is thinking an him.  43B.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Akator. He moves to his bedroom. INDY (cont’d) Akator. It would be the find of a lifetime. He goes to the closet. INDY (cont’d) Create a reputation no politician could touch. Indy picks up his hat- CLOSE ON THE HAT!  51

dialogues.speaker: 51B
dialogues.text: 51Cc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of dissolves takes place against a moving map wi animated red line. From the East Coast they make their way southwest to Mexi Mexico City airport Mutt’s motorcycle is being carted towards the cargo hold ‘PANAGRA’ plane. Mutt watches them, Indy tips one of the Indy carries a rucksack. As the red line moves toward the desert coast of Peru,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mutt is busy cleaning his bike, Indy watches him, he trie some sleep. The plane continues traveling Indy and Mutt are looking out the window, the plane makes Indy and Mutt move to the other side of the plane. There, scratched into the desert floor below, are the actual Naz Lines. The red line reaches its end The Panagra plane takes off again, revealing Indy, the bi Mutt standing in a desert airstrip, with a few chickens r around.

dialogues.speaker: EXT NAZCA DAY
dialogues.text: The windswept desert city of Nazca is like Casablanca -- international, dangerous. And hot. Always, everywhere, ho Mutt’s motorcycle is chained to a metal post outside a ca the edge of a town square. Mutt’s at an outdoor table bes finishing a bottle of Coke, adding it to a pyramid of fiv in front of him. Looks bored, he’s been there a while. Indy is nearby, speaking to a couple LOCALS in Spanish, g an animated story from them. He finishes and rejoins Mutt

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Finally -- they saw him. Ox came wondering into town a few months ago, raving like a mad man. The police locked him up in a sanitarium. It’s this way.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Me motto. He starts walking. Mutt falls into stride alongside him. MUTT (CONT’D) I took Spanish, man, I didn’t understand a word of that. What was it?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Quechua. Local Incan dialect.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Where’s you learn that one?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Long story.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: I got time.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I rode with Pancho villa. A couple of his guys spoke it.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Bull-shit!

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You asked.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Pancho Villa?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Technically, I was kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: By Pancho Villa?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It was the fight against Victoriano Huerta. Indy SPITS on the ground at the mention of Huerta’s name.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: How old were you ?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: ‘bout your age.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Your parents musta lost it, huh?.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: thins were -- a little tense at home.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Things are a little tense between me and my mom right now.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Treat her right, kid, you only get one. (muttered) And sometimes not for long.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: It ain’t my problem(my fault), it’s hers. She got P.O.ed cause I quit school, like I’m some kind of goof or cause I quit school.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You quit school?  45A.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Sure, tons of ‘em. Fancy prep schools. Teach you chess, debate, fencing: I’m great with a blade. I just think it’s a waste of time.  53 46.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You never finished?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Nah, it’s all useless skills and the wrong books. I mean, I love reading, Ox made me read all the time. Now I can pick ‘em myself, you get me.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What do you do for money?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Fix motorcycles.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Plan on doing that forever?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Maybe I will, teach. You got a problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: No, not if that’s what you love doing, don’t let anybody tell you any different. As they head toward the hulking sanitarium at the end of street, the brim of a Panama hat rises in the foreground. Somebody’s watching them. The head turns, and we get a go at him as Indy and Mutt walk away. It’s Indy’s old friend Mac.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SANITARIUM DAY
dialogues.text: The looming facade of the sanitarium. Indy and Mutt walk it, and Indy reads the words carved over the door

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Saint Anthony de Padua.(this is it)- (here we are) (sees the irony) The patron saint of lost things.  46A. RETAKE 8-31-07 -A PERUVIAN NUN opens a gate, Indy and Mut She speaks in Spanish, Indy translates, while Mutt trails They head down the steps into a corridor in the sanitariu Indy and the

dialogues.speaker: PERUVIAN NUN, (IN SPANISH)
dialogues.text: Ne se donde esta el, pero te voy a mostrar la celda. Vinieron hombres armados. Hombres malos y se lo llevaron. (I don’t know where he is, I will take you to his cell. Armed men came. Bad men and they took him) Estaba obsesionado con la pintura, pintaba toda las paredes al borde de la locura. ( he was obsessed with painting, he painted all the walls he was crazy)

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: She says Ox, he’s not here now(he isn’t here)She’s going to show us the cell. She doesn’t know where he is(where he want) some men came and took him away, man with guns. She says Oxley was obsessed, deranged, drew pictures all over the wall of the cell. Nun continue down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: PERUVIAN NUN
dialogues.text: Estaba obsesinado con la pintura. Pintaba todas las paredes. Lo Dejo hasta el borde de la locura.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: She says he was obsessed, deranged, he drew pictures all over the walls of his cell. MUTT looks into the cells, freaked out by the INMATES beh bars on either side of the stone hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: El sabia que se me pegaba.(he knew it was sticking to me) y lo pique, lo pique, lo pique( and I stabbed him, and stabbed him , and stabbed him) The Nun moves ahead to a certain cell and begins to open lock. Indy takes out Oxley’s letter. He and Mutt stand ne  46B.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: This riddle of Oxley’s makes no sense”...follow the lines only the gods can read leads to Orellana’s cradle.” Cradle? Cradle? birth, Orellana wasn’t born in Peru, he was born in Spain. He was a Conquistador, he came here for gold.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Disappeared along with six others. Their bodies were never found. The nun unlocks the door-- Indy and Mutt enter the cell.  54 47.

dialogues.speaker: INT SANITARIUM DAY
dialogues.text: Indy and Mutt walk down an endless corridor in the sanita led by a PERUVIAN NUN. She and Indy converse in whispered Spanish while Mutt tra them, freaked out by the INMATES behind the bars on eithe of the stone hallway. SCRATCHY CLASSICAL MUSIC plays on a record player.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Este hombre ha pasado todo el limite de la locura. Esta completamente obsesionado. La obsesion fue tan grande. que ha pasado el limite de la locura. Esta completamente obsesionado de la pintura. No Ha dejado una pared sin pintar. Todo parece loco. Obsesionado Hay Professor Jones esta completamente transtornado. Ha pintado todas las paredes. Es una obseion qui tiene con las pinturas. La obsesion de este hombre come esta transtornado no se puede explicar. Su mente esta totalmente transtornada. Esta obsesionado con las pinturas en las paredes. A pintado de dia y de noche. A dejado todo pintoado. Indy takes out Oxley’s letter and reads it. Suddenly one of the inmates lunges forward and grabs Mutt jacket, he has his hands on Mutt, pulling him toward them -- Indy’s hand clamps down on Mutt’s jacket and pulls him The Inmate yells , in Spanish, it’s as if he’s speaking i tongues-- some clear some not.

dialogues.speaker: INMATE
dialogues.text: El venia pero you no podia v er y llegaba la sangre. Acercaba. Agarre y lo picaba y lo picaba y me quieria matar y lo picaba y lo picaba. El caia ensima de mi. The Nun moves quickly out of the way, Indy and Mutt follo

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: She says Oxley was deranged. Obsessed. He drew pictures all over the walls of his cell.  55

dialogues.speaker: ATA. 10/17/07
dialogues.text: INDY (cont’d) “...follow the lines only the gods can read... leads to Orellana’s cradle.”(musing to himself)

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: “...follow the lines only the gods can read leads to Orellana’s cradle.” Cradle? Makes no sense, Orellana wasn’t born in Peru, he was born in Spain. He was a Conquistador, he came here looking for gold.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Disappeared along with six others. Their bodies were never found. The nun stops at a certain cell, unlocks it --

dialogues.speaker: INT CELL DAY
dialogues.text: -- and swings the metal door wide open. Indy and Mutt ste the room, which is about twenty feet square. Very spare, sink, two small windows, and a stone floor But what immediately catches their attention is the walls The lady wasn’t kidding, Oxley was obsessed, and has inde pictures on the stone walls of his cell. Pictures of the Crystal Skull.  48. They’re EVERYWHERE. Big versions, small ones, abstracts - dozens and dozens of drawings of the skull, smothering th walls. The far wall is one great big drawing, and Ox has the small square windows for the skull’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Ox, man, what happened to you? Indy turns, notices the emotion on Mutt’s face. He watche for a moment, realizing the depth of his connection with Mutt notices Indy noticing and turns away, embarrassed. Indy looks back to the drawings, studying them. In the pr drawings, the back of the head is elongated.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: This isn’t anything like the Mitchell- Hedges skull. Look at the cranium-- the elongation. There’s something else written on the walls of the cell - series of words, but not different words, they’re: INDY (cont’d) the same word, over and over, in different languages. Mutt finds one in Spanish and translates:

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: “Return.” Return where?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Or “what.”  56 57

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You mean the skull? Indy gestures to the drawings, makes the understatement o year.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Seemed to be on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Where was he supposed to return it to? He goes back down to his notes, studying the lines from t letter that he transcribed. Indy looks down. At the floor. He notices something. Drop his knees and runs his fingertips across the floor. He fi groove there, something scratched in the floor. He traces along the line, finds another, and another, som has carved lines into the soft stone floor

dialogues.speaker: BACK OUT IN THE HALLWAY,
dialogues.text: Indy grabs a broom from the Janitor’s cart.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE CELL,
dialogues.text: BAM! The broom flies at Mutt, who catches it with one han in front of his face.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Sweep. Indy goes to the far wall and starts to climb it, hoistin himself up onto the window ledge, then climbing to the ne ledge, getting higher and higher When Indy’s a good ten feet off the ground, he turns back looking at the area Mutt has swept clean. INDY (cont’d) Ox didn’t mean Orellana’s birthplace- cradle means more than one thing in Mayan, literally it’s resting place, as in ‘final’ resting place. He meant his grave, and that ---drawing he scratched into the floor  50. Through the cloud of dust and dirt, we can see a drawing’ carved into the floor of the cell, but this elaborate ren isn’t a skull, it has the jagged peaks of burial temples gravestones. INDY (cont’d) -- is the cemetery where he’s buried.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: but you said Orellana vanished. Nobody ever found his grave.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Looks like Harold Oxley did. As we stare at this outline of a specific cemetery a FLAS

dialogues.speaker: EXT CHAUCHILLA CEMETERY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mutt covers his motorcycle, in the moonlight. He is holdi backpack and a flashlight, he walks up the steps and join Indy finds two shovels. A hand-painted sign on a gate CREAKS in the wind:

dialogues.speaker: MATAREMOS A LOS HUAQUEROS
dialogues.text: Mutt reads the sign:

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: “Grave robbers will be shot!” Indy grins.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Good thing we’re not grave robbers. He throws the one of the shovels to Mutt. Lightning CRACKS behind him. He turns and walks into the cemetery, as he goes through archway. Mutt follows reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: DEEPER IN THE CEMETERY,
dialogues.text: half the graves have been strip mined, pillaged over the revealing skeletons in bizarre burial postures. There are skeletons strewn about, the place is in a state of disrep Two skeletons have been leaned up against grave markers, out in the open. It’s dark, Indy and Mutt lit only by the moon and the fli glow from the flashlight. Dirt and sand blow everywhere. they march against the wind. They walk in deeper into the cemetery. Chauchilla Cemetery is on a cliffside, partially eroded f below, leaving a promontory. It’s nighttime, a thundersto blowing in. Lightning CRACKS, and in that flash we see th lines, lit up on the desert floor hundreds of feet below. A SHADOWY FIGURE, which has blended into the branches, se materialize right out of the tree. Catlike in his grace b definitely human, he slinks across the tree branch, follo Indy and Mutt into the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What are we looking for?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. Something that doesn’t look right. Maybe an antechamber off one of these open barrows. One of the skeleton creatures moves out of a hole, and st to follow them, he jumps into another hole and disappears Mutt flinches, whirling around to look behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Thought I saw somethin’.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You’re jumping at shadows. They’ve reached a cliff. Mutt drops his shovel into the o and gets on a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: This way down. As he is about to take a step down, the ladder disintegra he falls flat on his back. Indy looks at him for a beat, then he starts to climb dow steps. He reaches Mutt, and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: This way up. Mutt takes his hand and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: SLAM
dialogues.text: Indy and Mutt are knocked to the ground by A SHADOW that of the tree branches above. NITO kicks Indy down. Indy hi wall and falls down a set of steps to a lower ground. Nit Mutt, and immediately disappears back into a hole. Mutt falls backwards, and suddenly the lone skeleton, (ER comes out of the hole from behind and pounces on him! We see it’s a real, living human being, dressed in a suit to disguise itself. Mutt whirls the figure around, they struggle. Indy reacts and gets up, he grabs the shovel and runs to Mutt ducks at the last moment, Indy hits the creature wit shovel. The bones SHATTER, revealing a human face behind. Before Indy can hit again, the figure slips away under In legs and trips him. He runs into another hole. Mutt gets the shovel and CLICKS open his switchblade, he to go after the figure into the hole. He hears something turns... NITO (the 2nd warrior)comes out of the hole with a_ blowd he raises it and aims at Mutt..

dialogues.speaker: THWACK
dialogues.text: A BLOWDART hits Mutt’s shovel handle. Mutt looks at it. N about to fire again. Mutt takes his knife flips it in his hand and hurls it-- -- and it grazes the Warrior’s shoulder, drawing blood, a throwing off his aim. The Warrior drops the blowgun, and the knife out from his wound. He starts to stand and cock arm to hurl it a Mutt, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy’s got his whip out. The lash wraps around Nito’s wri wrenches the knife free. It THUMPS to the dirt, Nito jump and runs into the same hole that Ernie went in. Indy sees Mutt is alright and follows Nito into the hole. Mutt looks around frantically. He hits the skeleton next still searches for anyone coming, suddenly he senses some and slawlyv tiirns toa see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie comes out from one of the arches carrying the blowd gun. He gets ready to shoot at Mutt. --Mutt winces, he’s toast for sure-- -- but suddenly A HAND closes over the barrel of the blow -- INDY’S HAND! -- -- and he yanks the gun toward himself and BLOWS SAVAGELY the wrong end of the barrel. The Warrior GASPS, his eyes go wide as the poison dart fl up the tube, JABS into the back of his throat, and kills Suddenly behind Mutt another WARRIOR, holding a bone, lun toward him. Mutt is about ready to start the fight. -- Indy pulls his revolver, COCKS it -- -- and the Warrior changes his mind, scurrying up and out grave and disappearing into the darkness. Mutt has been watching with wide eyes. He looks up and se standing there, whip in one hand, gun in the other, LIGHT THUNDER CRACKING behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You’re a teacher?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Part-time. He UNCOCKS his gun. Mutt picks up his switchblade. He notices there’s a smear blood on the blade.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: I never really used it before.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You did good kid. Indy strips the hat and burial serape from one of the ske wraps the poncho around the dead warrior that just attack and shoves the hat down on his head. Sitting up against t of the gave, he looks exactly like the other corpses.  54. INDY (cont’d) That oughta keep him for a couple hundred years. Indy sees a lantern Indy and Mutt head down deeper into the cemetery. Mutt is carrying the lantern.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Who were those things?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Nazca Indians. (thinking) Or their descendants. Sure didn’t like us poking around. (to himself) What are(were) they protecting? They reach the bottom and enter into .....  54a. They’re at a dead end, a stone wall dotted with various n with skulls and bones, covered in cobwebs.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Dead end.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Maybe. Mutt takes out his comb and begins to comb his hair. Indy him. INDY (cont’d) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Put that thing away. Give me some light over here. (bring it over here) Mutt moves closer to Indy. Indy looks down, sees a couple sets of dusty footprints l to and from the wall. One of the niches in the wall has a wedged in, and as Indy bends down for a closer look, he s cobwebs in the skull’s nose and mouth are moving. As if the skull is breathing -- or blown by circulating a Indy’s face lights up. He pulls the skull out by the eye and sees a looped rope inside the niche. He pulls on the rope and the rocks CREAK open, revealing passageway. Excited, Mutt lunges backwards -- And lands next to one of the skeletons, his arm on top th -- and a dozen SCORPIONS stream out over his arms. The biggest one raises its stinger and sinks it into Mutt right hand.

dialogues.speaker: GAAAAH
dialogues.text: Indy starts to go through the opening. Mutt is jumping ar brushing himself, frantic, trying to get the scorpions aw from him.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Dance on our own dime, will ya.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Scorpions! One of ‘em bit me! I’m gonna die!

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: How big?

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Huge!

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Oh, good.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (turns back) When it comes to scorpions the bigger the better. (another thought) A small one bites you, don’t keep it to yourself. And he’s gone, into the tunnel. Mutt follows.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: I’1l keep it to myself.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: INT TUNNEL NIGHT
dialogues.text: Indy starts to go down a set of stairs, Mutt follows. He gets startled -- he is facing a skeleton, buried uprig recess in the tunnel walls, their arms and legs bound acr their chests, their dead eyes staring at him. Indy, who was ahead, turns back

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: They’re not going to bite you. Let’s go. They continue down the stairs, Mutt looks at the skeleton reach the bottom, Mutt walks up to one of them, holding u lantern up to the head.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Their SKULLS! Look at their skulls man! Indy comes up next to him, he shines the flashlight on th The skull is bizarre. The back of the cranium is elongate shaped.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Like the drawings in Oxley’s cell. It means we’re getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: it’s crazy. Why’s it like that?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Nazca Indiana used to bind their infants head with rope to elongate their skull like that.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Honor the gods. Indy moves towards another opening.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: No, no. God’s head is not like that, man.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Depends on who your god is. Tree antare tha ananinag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy enters the opening he crawls onto a large Mayan Cale moves across.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Calendar, typical early Mayan. As he does the disc begins to tilt up covering Mutt’s vie other end. Mutt is still holding onto the lantern in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: This is(You’re) going nowhere fast. Don’t you think we should go the other way. Professor aren’t we suppose to be looking for an exit. This is really a dead end. Indy reacts to the disc moving. He moves closer and looks the other opening. Indy, goes back to Mutt. The disc tilt as he approaches Mutt opening the view.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: That’s it, c’mon genius. Indy starts to head back. INDY (cont’d) Bring the backpack, c’mon. Mutt starts to follow Indy.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy throws his backpack into the crawl space. He slides still carrying his flashlight. Mutt races to catch up to the narrow space. But as he scrambles forward on his hand knees, the floor buckles and his right hand, falls deep i hole. He claws for a grip on the sides of the floor, he gets ba onto the firm ground. Indy hurries back.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You alright? Mutt nods. INDY (cont’d) The earth’s (grounds) eroded out from underneath us. We’re on a promontory. Mutt, safe for the moment, catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: That’s good to know.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Be careful. And he’s gone again, crawling away into the tunnel, with backpack.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Be careful.(under his breath) He starts to follow Indy. Indy is staring out to the opening. Mutt comes up right n him. Indy stops him.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Hold it. They listen, then move out.  62 56.

dialogues.speaker: INT UNDERGROUND CHAMBER NIGHT
dialogues.text: Indy clears away the cobwebs and heads in... The lantern light emerges form the darkness into an under burial chamber. Indy comes out and looks around in awe. Mutt comes out of tunnel behind him.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: This is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Unreal. Mutt starts to move forward, Indy puts out an arm to stop from trampling the place.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Don’t touch anything. He waves the flashlight, exposing two sets of footprints dust. The footprints lead down the stairs and back out ag Indy and Mutt squat to get a closer look. INDY (cont’d) Somebody’s been here. Recently. (studying the prints) Two sets. Mutt looks at the tracks, measure them with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Same size. Could have been the same person, twice.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: (impressed) Not bad, kid. Indy walks down the stairs, trying to walk in the existin footprints. They lead to an object the size of a corpse, in a strange, material. Indy starts to count them.  57. INDY (cont’d) One...two...(turns and walks across the room)three (at a bottom one-lifts the flashlight up to) four... five... six... seven. (gestures with the flashlight) Orellana and his men. Might have made it out of the jungle after all. Indy moves to one of the bodies and tries to open the mat in which it’s wrapped. He tugs at it -- he puts his flash away.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Got a knife? Mutt takes out his knife and flips it in his hand. He han Indy. INDY (cont’d) Give me the light. Indy starts to cut the body. He pulls the wrapping back, another layer underneath, and pulls that back too. Indy r the body of a SPANISH CONQUISTADOR, five hundred years ol -- and perfectly preserved.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: It looks like he died yesterday. Indeed it does -- his body is intact, his clothes, his we even his skin.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It’s the wrappings, they’ve preserved him. The face begins to withered away to DUST! It shrivels and and within ten seconds it’s a pile of dust. Indy and Mutt are amazed.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It’s been wrapped up for 500 years. Air doesn’t agree with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy reaches inside the body. He pulls free a solid gold dagger with a jewel encrusted and holds it up to the lantern light, admiring it. Indy h Mutt his switchblade back. Indy starts to put the dagger in his satchel but--

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I was going to put it back. I don’t want to keep borrowing yours all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Indy returns the dagger -- Mutt moves to the other side of the crypt. MUTT (cont’d) is this one open already? Indy joins Mutt. The cocoon is torn open. There is a golden mask over the face of this corpse.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: It’s him! It’s Orellana himself.  58. Indy gestures to the skeleton, festooned with gilded armo INDY (cont’d) they called him, the gilded Man. What an incredible find. He stops himself, furrows his brow. Something’s not right points to the mask over Orellana’s face. Indy reaches out to the mask, runs his hand along the edg He closes his fingers around the mask and pulls it away s revealing the skull of Orellana himself, contorted in a h death shriek. INDY (cont’d) His lust for gold was legendary. This is odd.. Indy crosses to the other side of Orellana, and squats by side. He picks some gold coins off the floor, studies the impressions. INDY (cont’d) Somebody already has been here and gone. Left all this gold and (all)these artifacts. What were they looking (Indy starts to get up) The coins are pulled by a magnetic force. They get stuck Orellana’s body. INDY (cont’d) For.... Indy goes to the body, reaches down and lifts Orellana’s and torso. He hands it to Mutt. INDY (cont’d) Hold this. Mutt is eye to eye with the screaming, dead face. Indy looks beneath where the corpse was lying. He reaches and carefully lifts the a skull away from the corpse. MUTT puts the skeleton down.

dialogues.speaker: ---- THE CRYSTAL SKULL OF AKATOR.
dialogues.text: Stunning. It was, indeed, cut form one piece of pure crys and is completely transparent, yet multi-faceted. Indy holds the Crystal Skull up to the lantern. The light through it, especially the eyes -- they’re lensed, the li focusing through the sockets in a penetrating gaze. There appears to be a second crystal, embedded in the brain cav opal in color, standing out against the skull’s bluish ti INDY (cont’d) Unbelievable. No tool marks... A single piece of seamless quartz. A coin gets stuck to the skull. Indy removes it. INDY (cont’d) Cut across the grain, no evidence of a lapidary wheel. It’s not possible, even with today’s technology. It would shatter. What is this thing? As Indy turns the skull, Mutt’s eyes widen in surprise, b the back of the skull’s head is egg-shaped, like the corp outside.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Look at he shape of the head. Maybe to the Nazca Indians...this was their god. Is this the one from...

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Akator. (Indy begins to pace)Maybe the Spaniards find the skull along with all this other booty. They head to their ships along the coast. Maybe the Indians catch up with them, where they get to squabbling amongst themselves. The Indians wrap ’em up and buried them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH HF  59A. Indy looks at the skull, then down at the footprints agai thinking aloud, piecing it together INDY (cont’d) Couple(500 centuries) hundred years later Oxley shows up, finds the skull, takes it away, maybe to Akator. Then he returns it here.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: “Return, return.” Like he wrote on the walls of his cell.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: He put it back where he found it. Why? Mutt’s switchblade flies out of his hand and CLINKS up ag the skull, pulled by the metal’s magnetic force. INDY (cont’d) Crystal is not magnetic.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: Neither is gold. Indy looks back at the skull, staring deeply into its eye

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What is this thing? He gazes deeper, and deeper, and the skull seems to glow response, or is it just reflecting light from the lantern Indy’s eyes grow wider, he’s transfixed, and it doesn’t s could possibly tear his eyes away from the thing. Even Mutt has noticed the hypnotic quality of the skull, steps forward to look at it, now right behind Indy -- -- and the floor beneath them gives way! Mutt falls, but grabs hold of the leg of Orellana’s skele he goes down, through the floor --

dialogues.speaker: EXT CEMETERY DAWN
dialogues.text: As dawn breaks in the cemetery, Mutt and Indy climb out o open grave. But Indy stops in his tracks, coming face to with -- UNIFORMED RUSSIAN SOLDIERS on either side. Mac, Indy’s old friend, walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Hello, Jonesy.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Hello, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: EXT IQUITOS NIGHT
dialogues.text: Night has fallen on the outskirts of the jungle city of I the last toehold of civilization before the Amazon. A SOV ARMY REGIMENT is amassed in a makeshift camp on the edge clawing jungle. There are a dozen vehicles -- jeeps, trucks, one great bi Machine with a series of horizontal saw blades on the fro FIFTY RED ARMY SOLDIERS. The Russians are a celebratory bunch, some of them groupe a bonfire where a CRAZY RUSSIAN dances wildly. A small tent glows at the center of the camp, lit up by t lantern-light within. There are TWO GUARDS at the flap.

dialogues.speaker: INT TENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Inside the tent, Indy is sitting in a chair to which he h tied. Dovchenko is watching the tent. *  63. Mac enters, holding a bottle of liquor in one hand and a in the other. He walks up to Indy, smiling his most winni smile.

dialogues.speaker: MUTT
dialogues.text: You’re lucky I turned up Jonesey. Dovchenko wanted to blow your brains out That’s the three times I’ve saved your life, mate.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Unshackle me and I’11 give you a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You had a Luger pointed at the base of your skull when we first met.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: I had the situation under control.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Do you remember the amnesia darts I pulled out of your neck in Jakarta?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Amnesia darts?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: See, you don’t remember! Take my word for it, you owe me. Mac sits down, where a reel-to-reel tape recorder is turn table, recording every word.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: What about them? What do you owe them? After the war, when you turned -- how many names did you give the Reds? How many good men died because of you?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I don’t think you see the big picture, mate.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Eventually they’re going to let me out of this chair, comrade, and when they do I’m going to (bust)break your nose. Mac puts the bottle down and picks up the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: “Comrade?” You think this is about flags? This is about uniforms? about lines on a map?

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: it’s just about money, isn’t it? It’s

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: No, not “only money,” (he drops the microphone gets up and goes to Indy))a gigantic pile of money! Don’t worry about what the Russians will pay us, it’s nothing compared to what’s at Akator. An entire city of gold, it’s what the Conquistadors were after (looking, searching), for Dog’s sake Jonesey! We could be richer, richer than Howard Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Blood money. Every nickle of it. Mac leans in and lowers his voice. It’s stilted, as if Ma trying to tell Indy something.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I need you to see the angle here, mate, to be smart and do the right thing. Like in- Before he can finish, the lantern light flickers as someo pushes open the tent flap, letting in a breeze from outsi shadow falls across them both. Indy looks up. Irina Spalko stands behind Mac, dressed in Russian military fatigues. Mac doesn’t need to turn around, he knows perfectly well is. He finishes what he was saying to Indy, voice low -- MAC (cont'd) Like in Berlin. Get me? Just like Berlin. Mac heads out and walks past Spalko and Dovchenko. MAC (cont'd) You want me to jiggle out of here, or should I sing a song. Paddling Madeline. (he starts to sing) I love this girl called Madeline. I know she loves me too, cause every night the moon shines bright she rides in my canoe at midnight. -- and beats it out of the tent. Spalko sizes up Indy. eH FH HK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH HF  64a.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: How fortunate our failure to kill you Dr. Jones. You survive to be of service to us once again. She walks towards the recorder

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You know me, anything I can do to help.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: “Now I am become Death, the Destroyer of Worlds.” You recognize those words? It was your own Dr. Oppenheimer, after he created the atomic bomb. She turns off one of the switches and continues to move a Indy.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: He was quoting the Hindu Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac steps near the fire still singing his song(Paddling M Home )

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I love this girl called Madelin. I know she loves me too cause every night the moon shines bright she rides in my canoe at midnight. He is no longer drunk, he looks back at Indy’s tent.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: It was nuclear intimidation. But now this next level of weapon is ours to have -- yours to fear.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Weapon? What weapon? Spalko moves to the front and faces Indy, she leans on th with her leg.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: A mind weapon. A new frontier of psychic warfare; that was Stalin’s dream. Indy looks at her like she’s nuts.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Now I know why Oxley put the skull back where he found it. He knows you were after it.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: That skull is no mere deity carving. Surely you knew the moment you laid eyes on it -- it was not made by human hands. She leans forward and puts her hands on Indy’s legs.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Who made it then? (off her look) C’mon. She looks across the tent and moves.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: that body we found in New Mexico was not the first. Spalko walks across the tent into a side tent. There is a covered on a table. She starts to clean her hands with a SPALKO (cont’d) We’d already dissected two others from similar crash sites in Soviet Union.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Saucer-men from Mars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to 65A.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: The legends about Akator are all true. Early man couldn’t have conceived it, much less built it. It was a city of supreme beings, with technologies and paranormal abilities. the head of the table, Dovchenko standing next to her with a flashlight. She uncovers the head and

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: Why do you disbelief your own eyes. (Why Do you choose not to believe your own eyes? the body and reveals the alien form. Spalko moves opens the brain,exposing the crystal skull. SPALKO (cont’d) The New Mexico specimen gave us hope. Unlike the others we’d found, (this)its skeleton was pure crystal. A distant cousin, perhaps? Maybe they too were sent to find Akator. Perhaps we’re all searching for the same thing. There’s no other explanations

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: There’s always another explanation. Spalko washes her hands.

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: he skull was stolen from Akator in the 5th century. ba She walks back to Indy’s tent. SPALKO (cont’d) Whoever returns it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH HF

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: --to the city’s temple will gain control over its power. I’ve heard that bedtime story before. What makes you think Akator even exists. (But what if Akator never existed)(It’s a legend why do you think Akator even existed)

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should ask your friend that question.

dialogues.speaker: DOVCHENKO
dialogues.text: PRIRIDITYE PROFESSORA! (bring in the professor)

dialogues.speaker: SPALKO
dialogues.text: We’re certain he’s been there.

dialogues.speaker: INDY
dialogues.text: Oxley. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: EXT- RUSSIAN CAMP NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Crazy Guy is still dancing around it like a madman. H dressed in an old, battered suit, the arms and legs shred His hair is long and wild, and he’s flinging his body aro campfire with mad abandon while the Russians laugh and cl mocking him. A couple of he soldiers approach Oxley, grab him and take the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
